item.description: Hello! Hallo! 你好！ I’m Yutong Wang, a second year graduate student in Graduate Group of Biostatistics, at University of California, Berkeley, working in Prof. Yun S. Song’s group. I am broadly interested in statistical machine learning, causal inference and transfer learning, with applications in scRNA-seq and microbiome. Feel free to contact me: ytwang at berkeley dot edu

item.title: Education
item.description: Graduate Coursework: Theoretical Statistics, Advanced topics in Causal Inference, Probabilistic Modeling in Genomics, Statistical Models: Theory and Application I, II, Computational Statistics with Applications in Biology and Medicine Undergraduate Coursework: Functional Analysis, PDE, ODE, Real Analysis, Complex Analysis, Abstract Algebra, Stochastic Process, Probability, Mathematical Statistics, Statistical Inference, Optimization Methods, Modern Data Mining, Data Analytics & Statistical Computing, Computer Methods with Mathematical Science, C++, Advanced Calculus, Advanced Algebra, Analytical Geometry Awards:

item.title: Misc
item.description: I have been working as a journalist in the New Citizen Program in China since 2016, to raise sexual health awareness of the public, left-behind children in particular. I later realized credible statistics of domestic sexual crime is impossibly difficult to collect in my home country. Thus I’ve been consistently interested in data collection and statistical analysis about related social issues for the sake of public policy-making. I have published several articles as a journalist.

item.title: Research
item.description: My current research projects include: 1. Domain adaptation The incredible success of deep learning shows the potential of artificial intelligence to learn from complex large-scale whole-genome data in computational biology. However, it can be extremely expensive or time-consuming to collect and annotate data in biology. In the lack of sufficient data, biologists always leverage probabilistic modeling to generate datasets. However, deep learning-based attempts using simulated datasets always struggle with model misspecification, as real data often has additional noise which is not well-characterized in probabilistic modeling.

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Spring 2020: Concepts of Statistics (Stat 135), with Professor Adam Lucas (Lab Materials) Fall 2018 - Spring 2019: Introduction to Statistics (Stat 2), with Professor Cari Kaufman
